title: Incoming Scripting Suspensions
body:
Heya dudes,

This is just a heads up that we’re executing a fairly massive banwave on a good majority (all) of cheaters today.  I know we’re normally pretty silent about this type of thing (gotta keep our enemies in the dark), but seeing as how it’s probably the 3rd largest salt mine I’ve ever excavated, I figured we’d give a little advanced notification.

I’d also like to cunningly make use of everyone’s eyeballs as a [reminder](https://support.riotgames.com/hc/articles/225266848) that we’re definitely not into applications that provide measurable player advantage. The cheating we’re targeting here is primarily comprised of modifications that take actions on your behalf (affectionately called scripting), and that’s our least favorite type of mojo.  It’s probably been said before, but this is meant to be a fair videogame and you shouldn’t ever have to go digging for add-ons just to stay competitive.

We've got a lot of work to do in preventing this behavior from occurring in the first place, but rest assured, the banhammer won't stop swinging until the message really sinks in.

TL;DR - Bans for days.  Stop scripting.  Thanks!

Actually, Riot has punished players for intentionally exploiting bugs in the past. It's rare that they do it, but it has happened.

Normally if there is a major bug that can give people a very major advantage, Riot disables whatever it is that involves the bug, whether it be a champion or an item. However, sometimes there is no way to do this without majorly affecting the game, such as if the bug involves multiple champions.

There are multiple examples of this, but the most notable example that pops into my mind is the case of the instant recall bug, something that allowed you to instantly recall. It was originally though that only Riven can do it, but very quickly it became known that pretty much every champion could execute it. Because Riot couldn't just disable every champion until it was fixed, they decided to just disable rank so no one's rank was affected by this while they were working on a solution. However, they warned us that anyone caught abusing the bug before it was fixed would be punished.

The better your understanding of optimal micro positioning the easier it is to spot. The most common script I see in Korea is like dodge scripts. If you see a player instantly sidestep every single skillshot without fail even if it means moving them in a suboptimal direction that is probably scripting. If they're dodging things they don't need to or _shouldn't_ dodge it's probably cause they're scripting. Another key example of dodge script is if they sidestep even when they can't see you, and I think the sidestep should be instant. Another type of scripting that should be easy to spot is if they can auto cancel like a god i.e this guy https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=QzW1oET3n-8 Scripters who have scripts to make their skillshots always hit are a little harder to spot. I didn't think mouseclicks were something the in-game controls allowed to be reassigned. However, since it is just a simple rebind of a SINGLE key, it should be fine. Using a program to perform a skill+mouseclick would be getting into the slipper slope though.

The game literally has a command called "attack move click" that is a single-button version of pressing A then clicking the ground. You can assign it in the **in-game options** menu (though assigning it to mouse buttons requires changing a config file, it's still using the game options itself). No keyboard macro required - it's just rebinding keys. 99% sure it's fine.

Question, what is the official policy on things like replay.gg? I've heard from some people that that site can get you into trouble if Riot detects it but I've had no concrete evidence either way. I'm asking because I had a salty Evelyn in a game that wanted to report me and 2 other teammates for "hacking" when all it was is that we got fed. Even so, some of my friends told me I could be in trouble if they saw replay.gg on my account since it's a 3rd party program, even though it doesn't alter performance at all.

Replay isn't a third party program at all - they do literally nothing but scan for replays by using an API creatively, something Riot has explicitly allowed as long as that's the only thing they do with it.

Besides, Replay is all about looking at past games - it can't give you an edge in any way when playing.
Ok, cool. I'd heard reports otherwise and wasn't certain. thank you for clearing that up.

IMO if it cannot be done by just using what is available as-is in the game and game options, then it should not be allowed because then you're taking something that did not come with the game and adding to it to get an advantage over others. Even an auto-message is saving you precious time that could otherwise cost someone actions or split-second decision-making time to type out. In high elo games, split seconds can decide a fight, especially so against someone that can sneak up on you.

The only thing I'm concerned about is proof of what script was being used. In the past people have come out as saying they don't use scripts, riot says they do, and there is no proof offered. If someone does happen to be falsely tagged as using scripts how are they ever going to prove they didn't use one? How can they counter an accusation from someone who presents no proof?

Companies dont show evidence of cheaters because it makes it easier for the script creators to overcome their defences and make the script avoid the banning method used. Even if they learn it in time, it vastly delays them by doing so.
